PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NOTE OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON COMPLETING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE.

It is desirable to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will answer only his own experiences; others may prove impossible for him to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The answers should be given in detail, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Ones of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All Questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Some were very glad we would go too and others said Scotland was good enough place to live in. Our old lady said we would be happy to death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My mother and I.

13. What means of transportation did you use? By the civilian ship.

Allen Line from Glasgow

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement.)

Had two hours to view Dublin and took an horse.

Greenham, main host of the Montgomery Army Train.

When we changed some gold sovereigns into dollars and cents and got 4 dollars + 50 cents for each sovereign.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Nuck Lake, back.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Brighton back.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Burn Allard or New back.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you now?

Office supervisor in Edinburgh, City Hall, Scotland.

Farming. Before settling down I helped to build some of the big camps along which at that time mainly the Verandah Friends, the Van Pacific, the 670 R.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were very glad we would go there and they said Scotland was not good enough place to live in. One old lady said we would be frozen to death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? By mother and I.

13. What means of transportation did you use? By the civilian ship.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, etc.) We had two hours to view Quebec and met an honest Frenchman, many hotels of the Montgomery Arms Tavern, where we changed some gold sovereigns into dollars and ears and got 4 dollars & 50 cents for each sovereign.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? North Lake, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Brighton, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Prince Albert & Elmo, Sask.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How are you doing now? Office supervisor on Blairmore, North Dakota. After working down I helped to build some farming. After working down I helped to build some of the first wagons being built at that time—namely the Veteran Friends, the Van.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

My dear Mrs. Smith,

I will never forget the hardships we had to endure on our way to Canada. We traveled by horseback through the wilderness and faced many dangers. We had to cross rivers and streams, climb mountains, and navigate treacherous paths. Despite these challenges, we persevered and eventually reached our destination. It was a long journey, but we knew that we were making a new life for ourselves in Canada.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. I am enclosing a picture of our family. We hope you enjoy it.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first library club.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption. Give facts of new names above in (1), (2), (3).

The school was named after Mr. James Barrie. The creek was named after Mr. James Barrie. The hill was named after Mr. James Barrie.
37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

I was the first to grow crab apples, plums, cherries in this district. The first to plant a wind break or shelter belt. The wind break was planted in 1911.

I grew my first fruit in 1916. I have now 100 fruit trees.

Note: I really planted my first fruit trees when I planted my shelter belt but the rabbits got them before winter.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1); (2), (3).

"Mount Tiviot" is the name of our School District, the first school ever built here. The first trustees were Mr. Smart, Mr. Headrick, Mr. Ivy, and Mr. Barrie, chairman.

Each trustee sent in to the Ministry of Education at Regina a name for the new school. The name sent in by me being chosen. The name "Mount Tiviot" was taken from a "Mount Tiviot" a high hill near the Tiviot River on the estate of Lord Thirto in Roxburghshire in Scotland—a spot of rare beauty.

The school was built in 1912.

The name of Brighton, your district, is of U.S. origin.
37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

I was the first to grow crab apples, plums, cherries in this district. The first to plant a wind break or shelter belt. The wind break was planted in 1911.

I grew my first fruit in 1916. I have now 100 fruit trees.

Note: I really planted my first fruit trees when I placed my shelter-belt but the rabbits got them before winter.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

"Mount Deviot" is the name of our School District; the first school ever built here. The first trustees were Mr. Smart, Mr. Reddick, Mr. Irvin, and Mr. Barrie, Chairman.

Each trustee sent in to the minister of Education at Regina a name for the new school. My name was in by me being chosen. The name "Mount Deviot" was taken from a "Mount Deviot," a high hill near the Deviot River on the estate of Lord Thirto in Ross-shire, Scotland—a spot of rare beauty.

The school was built in 1912.

The name of Brighton, our district, is of U.S. origin.
